content:
Next week's talk will be given by Prakash Panangaden

Title: A categorical view of conditional expectation

Abstract: This talk is a fragment from a larger work on approximating Markov processes. I will focus on a functorial definition of conditional expectation without talking about how it was used. We define categories of cones---which are abstract versions of the familiar cones in vector spaces---of measures and related categories cones of Lₚ functions. We will state a number of dualities and isomorphisms between these categories. Then we will define conditional expectation by exploiting these dualities: it will turn out that we can define conditional expectation with respect to certain morphisms. These generalize the standard notion of conditioning with respect to a sub-sigma algebra. Why did I use the plural? Because it turns out that there are two kinds of conditional expectation, one of which looks like a left adjoint (in the matrix sense not the categorical sense) and the other looks like a right adjoint. I will review concepts like image measure, Radon-Nikodym derivatives and the traditional definition of conditional expectation. This is joint work with Philippe Chaput, Vincent Danos and Gordon Plotkin.

This talk is based on the following paper:

  • Philippe Chaput, Vincent Danos, Prakash Panangaden and Gordon Plotkin, Approximating Markov processes by averaging, in _International Colloquium on Automata, Languages, and Programming_, Springer, Berlin, 2009.
Prakash says those two versions are the same.

You can see Prakash's slides now:

  • Prakash Panagaden, A categorical view of conditional expectation.

Abstract. This talk is a fragment from a larger work on approximating Markov processes. I will focus on a functorial definition of conditional expectation without talking about how it was used. We define categories of cones—which are abstract versions of the familiar cones in vector spaces—of measures and related categories cones of Lp functions. We will state a number of dualities and isomorphisms between these categories. Then we will define conditional expectation by exploiting these dualities: it will turn out that we can define conditional expectation with respect to certain morphisms. These generalize the standard notion of conditioning with respect to a sub-sigma algebra. Why did I use the plural? Because it turns out that there are two kinds of conditional expectation, one of which looks like a left adjoint (in the matrix sense not the categorical sense) and the other looks like a right adjoint. I will review concepts like image measure, Radon-Nikodym derivatives and the traditional definition of conditional expectation. This is joint work with Philippe Chaput, Vincent Danos and Gordon Plotkin.

Don't forget to join us Wednesday April 8th at 5 pm UTC, which is 10 am in California, 1 pm on the east coast of the United States, or 6 pm in England. The talk will be held online via Zoom, here:

https://ucr.zoom.us/j/607160601

We will have discussions online here—I suggest coming here 20 minutes before the talk, for coffee and delicious cookies.

People will also discuss the talk afterwards.
Prakash's talk will start today at UTC 1700 = 10am in CA = 6pm in the UK.

Prakash's talk will be held online via Zoom, here:

https://ucr.zoom.us/j/607160601
This sounds so interesting! Can't wait to hear.

The slides, again, are here:

  • Prakash Panangaden: A categorical view of conditional expectation.
I'm being asked for a meeting password?
@John Baez I was also asked for a password.
Okay, yeah that was imposed by UCR. Wait a sec.
I've turned off the need for a password, but it's 632765 in case you need it.
Given the increase in zoombombing, it's a sensible precaution
Right. I think I'll risk it now.
Given that this is a talk, is there a way so that only a select few people can use cam/audio?
It's set up so that only I can share my screen right now.... and I'll give this privilege to Prakash.
The link for the Zoom meeting on the n-Cafe post seems broken; it should point to https://ucr.zoom.us/j/607160601 but has extra Markdown stuff
Whoops, I'll fix it.

Prakash has updated his slides and the new version is here:

http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/mathematical/ACTUCR/Panagaden_Conditional_Expectation.pdf
It's started...
i'm chewing some more on the definitions of cones—is it just me or do ω-complete ones get a unique action of R+ automatically if you have an action of Q
actually wait uhh... hmm
(basically i'm wondering how much of this is property as opposed to structure)
Is ω\omegaω-continuity stronger or weaker than continuity?
if by continuity you mean scott-continuity, it's weaker—dunno if it's strictly weaker
I was thinking that the norm on a cone would induce a topology
I don't know if that's the same
there's a thing on a dcpo (directed-complete partial order) called the scott topology, for which iirc the continuous functions are the same as the scott-continuous ones wrt the order
that's what i was thinking of
but i think the question of whether that kind of continuity automatically coincides with what you were saying is probably very much in line with what i was asking in the first place
Yes, the topology induced by the order is the Scott topology.

Concerning Arthur's question, I think it's interesting to think about it already when both measurable spaces are finite. Then one difference is that in Prakash's slides, alpha is just a map between the underlying sets, so there aren't really general Markov kernels around. Right?

But I was also wondering about whether there's any relation to the dagger functor of https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.02651
No, it is a map between the measurable spaces and it has to do the right things to the measures.
Someone asked if ω\omegaω-continuity was stronger or weaker than (norm) continuity.
Oscar Cunningham.
Stronger in this case.

Prakash Panangaden said:

No, it is a map between the measurable spaces and it has to do the right things to the measures.

yes, of course, I was referring to the case of finite and discrete measurable spaces for simplicity. So my point was just that it's a very special type of Markov kernel, namely a "deterministic" one
Yes, but see the paper to see how we use it to construct approximate Markov kernels.

@Oscar Cunningham - yes, the norm on the cone induces a topology, and so Prakash is saying ω\omegaω-continuity of maps between cones is stronger (in the current context) than continuity with respect to the norm topology.
Thanks!
However I have a feeling that examples that illustrate the difference can only be constructed using the axiom of choice!
Hey, Tobias, are you holding the PI workshop on categorical probability via Zoom?
Very likely. Examples showing that L_1 is not L_inf^* can only be constructed with the axiom of choice.

Prakash Panangaden said:

Hey, Tobias, are you holding the PI workshop on categorical probability via Zoom?

Yes, we're planning on a combination of Zoom and Youtube streaming (optional per speaker's choice) as for ACT; Paolo Perrone is helping us with that. But I'm also curious to see how this chat format works out.
I think I am not associating my responses correctly with the questions!
The only way I know how to do that is quote the question; you can click on a comment and quote it.
There's not enough "threading" in this discussion group for my taste.

John Baez said:

The only way I know how to do that is quote the question; you can click on a comment and quote it.

Like this?

Prakash Panangaden said:

John Baez said:

The only way I know how to do that is quote the question; you can click on a comment and quote it.

Like this?

Yes, like this. :slight_smile:

okay, interesting, it looks like the definition of an ω-complete normed cone is equivalent to, like... "the norm preserves and lifts countable colimits (sups)" (in the senses here https://mathoverflow.net/a/293199/149197)
Hmm, Sarah's comment makes me realize that maybe Prakash's "ω\omegaω-continuity" is just preservation of countable colimits (in the poset given by the cone).
Is that right, Prakash? I threw in the word "just" just to show I'm a category theorist.
Hey, Sarah re-edited her comment to make mine look dumber. :slight_smile:
Now it looks like I'm just saying exactly what she said.

John Baez said:

Hmm, Sarah's comment makes me realize that maybe Prakash's "ω\omegaω-continuity" is just preservation of countable colimits (in the poset given by the cone).

Exactly. But that is always what ω\omegaω-continuity meant even in "domain" theory.
Cool. I never learned domain theory.
Is there an obvious reason for which we can restrict to countable sequences as opposed to directed nets in this case?
I don't know, maybe Prakash knows but I'd guess restricting to countable sequences weakens the concept.
Everything has a real number norm, so how would you have an uncountable increasing sequence?
Here's a related question: any poset gets an "order topology". How is ω\omegaω-continuity related to continuity in the order topology?

Paolo Perrone said:

Is there an obvious reason for which we can restrict to countable sequences as opposed to directed nets in this case?

I think the norm controls that.

Paolo Perrone said:

Is there an obvious reason for which we can restrict to countable sequences as opposed to directed nets in this case?

Or put differently, what breaks if you require your cones to be more generally bounded directed complete and the maps to preserve all directed suprema?

@Oscar Cunningham - you probably can't have an uncountable increasing "sequence" of real numbers, whatever that means, but you can have an uncountable net of them, like the net of numbers [0,1] indexed by the set [0,1].

Tobias Fritz said:

Paolo Perrone said:

Is there an obvious reason for which we can restrict to countable sequences as opposed to directed nets in this case?

Or put differently, what breaks if you require your cones to be more generally bounded directed complete and the maps to be preserve directed suprema?

I am not sure. We should think about that. If everything is countable it does not matter but there are uncountable directed sets whose limits you cannot get from sequences.
The interval [0,1] is the sup of the sup of the uncountable set of finite subsets of [0,1] ordered by inclusion but no sequence can get you there.
I thought the concept of "normal state" involved some kind of countable continuity but the Wikipedia definition uses general nets:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_(functional_analysis)#Normal_states

Prakash Panangaden said:

Tobias Fritz said:

Paolo Perrone said:

Is there an obvious reason for which we can restrict to countable sequences as opposed to directed nets in this case?

Or put differently, what breaks if you require your cones to be more generally bounded directed complete and the maps to be preserve directed suprema?

I am not sure. We should think about that. If everything is countable it does not matter but there are uncountable directed sets whose limits you cannot get from sequences.

Ok thanks. One thing that at least still works is that integration as a functional on L^oo(\mu) indeed preserves all bounded directed suprema.

But the subtlety here is that this would not be true without quotienting by null sets, i.e. integration does generally not preserve directed suprema. That's one way in which L^oo(mu) is nice
A state \tau is called normal, iff for every monotone, increasing net H_{\alpha } of operators with least upper bound H, \tau (H_{\alpha })\; converges to \tau (H).
Combining Tobias' remark with the Wikipedia definition I just spouted, I guess integration on L^infinity[0,1] is a normal state.
I particularly like the duality of L^1 and L^oo cones, that's quite beautiful. Prakash, you mentioned that it was already known somewhere, right? Do you know where it was introduced?
(Here I'm thinking of L^infinity[0,1] as a von Neumann algebra so the Wikipedia definition applies.)
Is there some way of copying this discussion to a document that I can stare at? There are lots of interesting remarks.
I don't know - some Zulip expert would know.

Prakash Panangaden said:

Is there some way of copying this discussion to a document that I can stare at? There are lots of interesting remarks.

I don't know, but this thread is here to stay :)
@Paolo Perrone - I think Prakash & Co. sort of invented this duality of L^1 and L^infinity cones, but I think it has precursors elsewhere.

Paolo Perrone said:

I particularly like the duality of L^1 and L^oo cones, that's quite beautiful. Prakash, you mentioned that it was already known somewhere, right? Do you know where it was introduced?

I don't know anyone who said it like that but the people who were doing representations of C* algebra must have known it implicitly; else it is hard to understand why they would talk about normal states.

John Baez said:

Combining Tobias' remark with the Wikipedia definition I just spouted, I guess integration on L^infinity[0,1] is a normal state.

Yes, right. The normal states are given by Prakash's cone M_ub (I think). In von Neumann algebra terms, the Radon-Nikodym derivatives of measures in M_ub are exactly the "density operators" associated to the normal states
Right, Prakash - I was just gonna tell Paolo that analysts take a C*-algebra like L^infinity, whose dual is "too big", and trim it down using this concept of "normal state" I was just talking about.
I forget what M_ub is.
Oh, I see. Makes sense. Thanks!
Okay, I guess I remember what M_ub is.
Is Arthur in this chat?

I never got quite deep enough into C*-algebras to see why "normal states" are so great, but I guess it's precisely to eliminate things like the "weird" elements of the dual of L^infinity, and the "weird" states on the algebra of bounded linear operators, like the ones that vanish on all compact operators.
I have a question again. Is Rad_1 (and/or Rad_oo) an opfibration over Meas?
Hmm, I think only certain special measurable functions get to lift to morphisms in Rad_1 or Rad_infinity.

sarahzrf said:

(basically i'm wondering how much of this is property as opposed to structure)

I would love to understand this remark better.

Paolo Perrone said:

I have a question again. Is Rad_1 (and/or Rad_oo) an opfibration over Meas?

Can you remind me of the definition?
An opfibration is roughly a functor F: C -> D such that every morphism in D "lifts" in a really nice way to one in C.
It looks like the rate of comments has slowed down. Thanks for all your great comments. There is much to think about.
I was suggesting that Rad_1 -> Meas is not an opfibration because there are lots of morphisms that don't lift at all.
I need to leave now but I will check this link periodically.
Okay, see ya!
Ok, thank you so much for the talk! I hope to see you here in the future.

John Baez said:

Now it looks like I'm just saying exactly what she said.

not quite—i'm talking about ω-completeness itself :)
the property of the cone rather than of maps
also oops i meant specifically of shape ω, not just "countable"
i almost wrote that, too, but then i misread...

Paolo Perrone said:

John Baez said:

I was suggesting that Rad_1 -> Meas is not an opfibration because there are lots of morphisms that don't lift at all.

Why not?
(To avoid confusion: by Meas I mean measurable spaces, not measure spaces.)
man, i should learn about lawvere metric spaces

John Baez said:

Paolo Perrone said:

John Baez said:

I was suggesting that Rad_1 -> Meas is not an opfibration because there are lots of morphisms that don't lift at all.

Why not?
(To avoid confusion: by Meas I mean measurable spaces, not measure spaces.)

Look at the definition of Rad_1 and Rad_infinity. Both these are categories where morphisms are measurable maps with an extra property. So these are non-full subcategories of Meas. So their inclusions into Meas are not cofibrations.
i'm looking over these definitions of cones & whatnot and all i see is, like, lax monoidal functors and stuff :sweat_smile:
wait, oh my god

John Baez said:

John Baez said:

Paolo Perrone said:

John Baez said:

I was suggesting that Rad_1 -> Meas is not an opfibration because there are lots of morphisms that don't lift at all.

Why not?
(To avoid confusion: by Meas I mean measurable spaces, not measure spaces.)

Look at the definition of Rad_1 and Rad_infinity. Both these are categories where morphisms are measurable maps with an extra property. So these are non-full subcategories of Meas. So their inclusions into Meas are not cofibrations.

I think the objects have an extra structure, namely the measure. (Or am I getting confused?)
okay i just confused myself
@Prakash Panangaden is the multiplication on cones supposed to satisfy r(sv) = (rs)v?
that doesnt seem to be mentioned anywhere? i think i was taking it for granted

sarahzrf said:

Prakash Panangaden is the multiplication on cones supposed to satisfy r(sv) = (rs)v?

For s \in N that follows from distributing over addition, I think? r(3v) = r(v+v+v) = rv + rv + rv = r*3(v) ? Though maybe I am wrong about that first step?
that sounds right, yeah
actually no hold on
yeah we also need (r + s)v = rv + sv
for that to work
which... doesnt seem to be mentioned...
it does say "an action" of R^{≤0}, but since that was ambiguous i pulled up the paper and it mentions neither axiom :?
i think ill just assume they were intended until i get a response

anyway....... so the poset R⁺ w/ the standard ordering is a monoidal category under multiplication. if my assumption above was right, then we should have that the action of R⁺ on any given cone makes it an R⁺-actegory. then the lax-equivariant maps are the ones with rf(v) ≤ f(rv) for all r, v
hmm... that does include all of the linear ones
perhaps i am hunting a little too hard for optics here.

thinking about how i want normed spaces to be spaces over R⁺, and then bounded maps are sort of like ones that make the triangle commute, except that actually it's a square and it doesn't commute it's just lax, so i don't even know why im trying to do this

Paolo Perrone said:

I think the objects have an extra structure, namely the measure. (Or am I getting confused?)

You're right, sorry.

Let's see. We want to see if p:Rad1→Measp: \mathsf{Rad}_1 \to \mathsf{Meas}p:Rad1​→Meas an opfibration, where Meas\mathsf{Meas}Meas is the category of measurable space and measurable maps. I take a morphism f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y in Meas\mathsf{Meas}Meas. I pick an object X′∈Rad1X' \in \mathsf{Rad}_1X′∈Rad1​ and try to lift fff to some morphism f′:X′→Y′f' : X' \to Y'f′:X′→Y′.

I'll just try to do this in some reasonably canonical way. The object Y′∈Rad1Y' \in \mathsf{Rad}_1Y′∈Rad1​ should be a measure space over YYY, so I'll push the measure on X′X'X′ forward along the measurable map fff. Then we get a measure-preserving map of measure space and I think that's our f′:X′→Y′f' : X' \to Y'f′:X′→Y′ in Rad\mathsf{Rad}Rad.
I'm too lazy to check to see if this is a "cocartesian lift", as required for an opfibration.
But I've done the heavy lifting here.
Yep, that's kind of what I'm hoping for! I guess the rest is taken care of by the fact that the UB and almost continuity relations form preorders. Nice! :)

sarahzrf said:

i think ill just assume they were intended until i get a response

Yes, cones had better obey the laws (r + s)v = rv + sv and r(sv) = (rs)v; we couldn't do much without those laws.
For what it's worth, in the YouTube video description is says the talk was on the 1st April, so presumably a copy and paste from @John Baez 's talk?
Thanks, I just fixed that.
It was my fault.
@Joe Moeller thanks!
I missed the talk, unfortunately. Is there a recording? I browsed through the thread above, but didnt see a link ...

All talks at the ACT@UCR seminar are recorded and available here, along with links to slides and/or relevant papers, a schedule of forthcoming talks, etc:

https://johncarlosbaez.wordpress.com/2020/03/24/actucr-seminar/

This page has a link to our YouTube channel as well as links to videos of individual talks.
@Rongmin Lu Thanks

Prakash Panangaden said:

Is Arthur in this chat?

I am now! But I noticed you might not be checking this very often anymore? Thanks @Tobias Fritz for asking my question in the chat and sorry for not being here to be a part of that discussion. In regards to the question, yes, I was thinking that maybe the inner product equation Panangaden wrote is Bayes' rule (expressed without using denominators) specialized to the case when alpha is deterministic. The associated map on the function algebras is the pullback. When you work with Markov kernels, you use integration to extend the notion of pullback, but the equation itself does not change in form. Since the time I asked the question in your talk, I had time to read the original paper, but I haven't yet put the details together in my head since I'm less familiar with the ω-continuous aspects. When the underlying sets are finite, the formula agrees with Bayesian inversion in the way I understand it (since L_\infty is isomorphic to L_1 and Bayesian inversion is well-defined a.e.). Since alpha is deterministic, this is just a disintegration.

As for the infinite-dimensional setting, we know the story on the space level with measurable functions (that's the usual disintegration theory for standard Borel spaces). When we go to the function spaces, we have many options, all the L_p spaces for example. But only one of them has a multiplication operation to make sense of the Bayes condition (just so we have the same definition, I'm using the diagram (6.4) in https://arxiv.org/pdf/2001.08375.pdf adapted to the algebraic setting where the 2 to 1 map, depicted as a trivalent bullet, read from top to bottom is multiplication---see also (8.26)) and that's L_\infty with the probability measure viewed as a positive linear functional on the algebra. But Panangaden does not go this route and instead uses an (L_p, L_q) duality, and I'm not 100% sure why. Here's my guess, based on a first reading of "Dahlqvist Danos Garnier Kammar - Bayesian inversion by ω-complete cone duality" https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01429656/document. I believe that their Proposition 17 combined with Theorem 19 say that the inner product equation Panangaden wrote is indeed Bayes' equation. It seems that this approach of using ω-complete cones has the benefit of not requiring assumptions on the underlying measure spaces (standard Borel for example). Is that the main point?
(deleted)

The third talk in this series is about to happen! Thread here: https://categorytheory.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/229457-MIT-Categories.20Seminar/topic/September.203.3A.20Prakash.20Panangaden's.20talk
